Around the town there were continuous stone dykes, with four prineipal entrances or ports, and ultimately, as will be afterwards notieed, the dykes were supersede'd by a very sufficient wall. With its castle, the burgh had, therefore, a considerably defensive aspect. But the inhabitants did not alto- gether rely on these means of security. The dwellings on both sides of the High Street, and also some dwellings 111 the closes, were strongly built as bustel-houses. The name bastel-house was applied to a dwelling constructed with its ground floor as an arehed vault, the apartments above being reached by an outside stair.
